Q7-gen: This photo was taken in the Plaza do Obradoiro in front of the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, Galicia, Spain.
This picture was taken in Taroko Gorge (Taroko National Park), along the Liwu River in Hualien County, Taiwan.
This is the Prague Astronomical Clock (Orloj) mounted on the Old Town Hall in Old Town Square, Prague, Czech Republic.
This photo was taken on the pedestrian walkway of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California.
This is the City Hall in Manhattan Beach, California.
This is the old Ferrocarriles de Yucatán (Mérida train) station building in Mérida, Yucatán, Mexico.

This scene very much resembles a demonstration on one of the steep, cobblestone streets descending toward Cusco’s Plaza de Armas in southern Peru, with the Andes rising in the distance. A plausible coordinate for where this photo was taken is around:  
  
Latitude: –13.5171  
Longitude: –71.9782  
  
That point lies on Avenida El Sol (one of the main colonial‐era thoroughfares) just above Plaza de Armas, Cusco.

The officer’s shoulder patch is the distinctive keystone shape used by Pennsylvania law enforcement, and the streetscape—with hanging flower baskets, neon signage and a dense pedestrian crowd—strongly suggests downtown Philadelphia. A plausible spot would be near Reading Terminal Market, around 51 North 12th Street. Rough coordinates: 39.9526° N, 75.1652° W.

This image was taken in the Grampians National Park (Gariwerd) in western Victoria, Australia—specifically from one of the rocky outcrops near the Boroka Lookout area overlooking the rugged, eucalyptus-covered ranges.

A reasonably good guess would be that this is one of the “pink buses” you occasionally see in Quito, Ecuador—likely somewhere in central Quito, for example along Avenida Amazonas near the TelefériQo junction (about latitude -0.1807, longitude -78.4678).
This photo was taken aboard the National Park Service “P‐Town Shuttle” at the Cape Cod National Seashore in Provincetown, Massachusetts.

I’m afraid I can’t point to an exact street‐address or GPS coordinate for this scene – there simply aren’t enough unique landmarks or signage in the frame to do so. My best (very tentative) guess is that it was shot in a makeshift housing block or temporary shelter corridor – something akin to the older container camps you’ll still find on the northern fringes of Calais, France (around latitude 50.95° N, longitude 1.85° E). But again, with no distinctive markers visible, any specific lat/long I give is highly speculative.

This appears to be a “color run”–style event, most commonly held as a 5K fun run in public parks. A frequent venue for large-scale color runs is Central Park in New York City, often centered on the Great Lawn. A plausible coordinate for such an event would be:  
  
Latitude: 40.7812° N  
Longitude: –73.9665° W
This photo was taken at the Stern Grove Festival grounds in Sigmund Stern Grove Park, San Francisco.
This is a street‐level view of a Loop office/retail block in downtown Chicago, at the corner of State Street and Madison Street in the Chicago Loop.
This is the Old Well on the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s campus, where students famously gather—especially at night—to celebrate big wins or events.
This picture was taken at Chanticleer Point (the Portland Women’s Forum State Scenic Viewpoint) overlooking the Columbia River Gorge, with Mount Hood in the distance.
This photo was taken on Grafton Street in central Dublin, Ireland.
This is the Baroque façade of the Basílica de Santa María del Coro on Calle de la Trinidad in the Parte Vieja (Old Town) of San Sebastián, in the Basque Country of northern Spain.
The photo was taken on the grounds of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C.
This image was taken in Cambridge, Massachusetts—during a Pride parade in Harvard Square.
This photograph was taken at Kiyomizu-dera, the famous Buddhist temple in Kyoto, Japan.

I can’t be certain, but my best guess is that this scene was shot in a flat, temperate agricultural region in northwest Europe. For instance, it could plausibly be somewhere in the Dutch province of Utrecht, near Amersfoort. A representative coordinate would be:

Latitude: 52.1500° N  
Longitude: 5.4000° E  

This spot lies in open farmland with the low hedges and cloudy skies very much like those in the photograph.

Based on the light-colored dune sand, the low grassy marram clumps, the simple hand‐tended gill net and float line, and the generally cool, clear light, my best guess is that this is a small fishing beach on Poland’s Baltic coast—around the dunes just east of Łeba. A plausible coordinate for this scene would be approximately  
Latitude: 54.75° N  
Longitude: 17.55° E

This outcrop—the steeply dipping, cross‐laminated sandstone and the pinon–juniper scrub in the background—matches the classic beaches and shallow‐marine sands of the Jurassic formations exposed in southern Utah. In fact, it was shot in the Grand Staircase–Escalante National Monument, on the west side of the Escalante River canyon.

This image was almost certainly shot atop Skyline Drive in Shenandoah National Park, Virginia (along the Blue Ridge Mountains). The rolling, forested ridges and stone overlook are classic features of that park’s many scenic pull-outs.
This photo was taken in Melbourne, Australia, right outside Flinders Street Station in the city’s central business district.
This photo was taken at Nikkō Tōshō-gū (日光東照宮) in Nikkō, Tochigi Prefecture, Japan.
This photo was taken at the Parthenon on the Acropolis hill in Athens, Greece.

A reasonable guess would be that this scene was captured in one of Johannesburg’s townships – for example, Soweto at approximately  
Latitude: –26.27°  
Longitude: 27.85°
This is the peristyle garden of the J. Paul Getty Villa museum in Pacific Palisades (Malibu), California.

Based on the style of beekeeping kit, the temperate‐meadow setting with hedgerows and spring wildflowers, and the typical protective veils in use, my best guess would be that this was taken in the United Kingdom.
This looks like it was shot at a Renaissance‐faire–type event in the United States. My best guess is the Texas Renaissance Festival near Todd Mission, Texas.
This picture was taken in Cleveland, Ohio, from the top deck of a tour bus parked on Wade Oval Drive in University Circle, looking toward the Cleveland Museum of Art.
This photo was taken inside the Tetsudō Hakubutsukan (The Railway Museum) in Ōmiya, Saitama Prefecture, Japan.

My best guess is that you’re looking at the famed stretch of Avenida de Mayo (or 9 de Julio) right in front of the Argentine National Congress in Buenos Aires, Argentina. In recent years it’s become a common gathering point for the “green scarf” abortion-rights movement, whose supporters have carried the very same green banners and held up portrait panels of women who died from clandestine abortions.

Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude  –34.6078  
Longitude –58.3816
This photograph was taken amid the ruined granite temples at Hampi in Karnataka, India.

This looks very much like a small, rural Thai Buddhist temple courtyard during a merit-making ceremony (note the saffron-robed monks on a red-and-gold platform, the traditional Thai umbrellas, and the simple grey-tiled outbuildings). I can’t pinpoint the exact temple, but a plausible rough location would be in central Thailand, in the greater Bangkok region. For example, a set of coordinates that would fall in the kind of semi-urban/rural temple complexes you see here would be about:  
  
Latitude: 13.75° N  
Longitude: 100.50° E  
  
If I had to guess a little more precisely, somewhere around 13.74°N, 100.52°E (in the outer districts of greater Bangkok) would be typical of the setting you’re seeing.
This photograph was taken in a front garden on a residential street in London, England.
This photo was taken in Copenhagen, Denmark, at the Langelinie promenade by the famous “Little Mermaid” statue.

A likely candidate for this kind of large, organized “zombie walk” in front of newly built or under-renovation apartment blocks would be Berlin, Germany—an urban setting where such events are popular and where you often see scaffolding on modern residential buildings. A plausible coordinate to start with would be:  
52.5200° N, 13.4050° E (central Berlin)
This snapshot was taken in central London (West End), just outside a little pub on the edge of Covent Garden.
This photo was taken at the Templo Mayor archaeological site in the Historic Center of Mexico City, Mexico.

This picture was taken in Japan, in Tokyo – along one of the Tamagawa-Josui (Tamagawa Aqueduct) walking paths in western Tokyo, where cherry trees line the canal’s embankment and burst into bloom each spring.

This looks very much like a hillside infinity‐edge pool at a warm-climate resort rather than a private backyard. My best guess would be somewhere like the Ko Olina resort area on Oahu (near 21.339° N, 157.997° W).
This is the ticket‐hall/entrance concourse of Baker Street station on the Metropolitan line of the London Underground.
This was shot in the tropical bamboo forest along the Pipiwai Trail in Haleakalā National Park on the east side of Maui (near the town of Hāna), in the famous “Bamboo Forest” section of the hike.

I’m not aware of any published record tying that exact concrete spillway (with the twin‐trunked channel and LEGO figure for scale) to a known landmark, so I can’t give you precise coordinates.  My best educated guess is that it’s a small 19th- or early 20th-century sluice or fish-ladder feature in a temperate European forest park—structurally and materially it looks a lot like minor water‐management works you’d find in southern Germany or Austria.

If I had to pick a set of coordinates that are at least in the right ballpark for that style of installation, I’d suggest around  
  51.7900° N, 10.9667° E  
(which places you in the wooded foothills of the Harz Mountains, Germany).  

Again, this is only an approximate guess based on construction style, scale and surrounding vegetation.
This is the Ho Chi Minh City People’s Committee Building (often still called the former Saigon City Hall) on Lê Duẩn Boulevard in District 1, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.
This is in central Rome, Italy – you’re looking at the front entrance (and its ornate wrought-iron gate) of a Baroque church in the historic heart of the city.
This snapshot was taken on Manhattan’s High Line park in New York City.

A very likely spot is along one of Amsterdam’s central canals – for example the Prinsengracht near the Jordaan district. A reasonable coordinate to drop a pin on would be:  
Latitude: 52.3740° N  
Longitude: 4.8850° E
This snapshot was taken in Tokyo, Japan—on one of the small public lawns in the Roppongi Midtown complex.
This appears to be a corporate boardroom high up in a Midtown Manhattan office tower, overlooking neighboring glass‐and‐steel skyscrapers in New York City’s business district.
This looks very much like one of the little cafés under the plane trees along the Seine in Paris, right beside the fountains of the Tuileries Garden.
This is the weekly market set up under the historic “Lauben” (arcades) in the Old Town of Bern, Switzerland.
This photo was taken outside the Hôtel Lutetia on the Rive Gauche in Paris, located at 45 Boulevard Raspail in the 6th arrondissement.
This photo was taken at the base of the Tokyo Skytree in the Sumida ward of Tokyo, Japan.

I’m reasonably confident this isn’t London or Edinburgh at all but a small‐town street in the Republic of Ireland – the orange “ROAD CLOSED / DIVERTED TRAFFIC” boards and the white‐fronted R-plates on the car point that way, as do the roughcast rendered walls and narrow pavements right up against the houses.  

My best guess would be somewhere like the main street of Dungarvan in County Waterford (approximate co-ordinates 52.08° N, 7.60° W).
This is a pedestrianised high street in Falkirk, Scotland – you’re looking toward the old parish church from Falkirk High Street.
This shot was taken on Naoshima (直島), the little art island in Japan’s Seto Inland Sea (Kagawa Prefecture), on the white seaside steps just in front of the Benesse House art site.
This image was taken at a medieval‐themed Renaissance festival—specifically the Texas Renaissance Festival in Todd Mission, Texas.
This image was taken at one of the popular cliff-jumping/swimming holes along Boulder Canyon just outside the city of Boulder, Colorado.
This view is looking out from the National September 11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, New York City.
This shot was taken in downtown Toronto on Yonge Street during the Pride parade—specifically in the vicinity of Yonge & Dundas.
This photo was taken on Mulberry Street in the Little Italy neighborhood of Lower Manhattan, New York City.
This photo was taken in Boston, Massachusetts, right in Copley Square on Boylston Street, just in front of the Old South Church.
This photo was taken in Palermo’s historic center, in the La Vucciria neighborhood of Sicily, Italy.
This appears to be a small public park in Washington, D.C. – specifically, a bench along the perimeter of Dupont Circle on Connecticut Avenue.
This image was shot on the Rockaway Beach boardwalk in Queens, New York City.

This photo was taken in San Francisco, California—at the Embarcadero cable‐car turnaround/Plaza area, looking southwest toward the Hyatt Regency and the 555 California Street building in the Financial District.
This photo was taken on a country road just outside Salisbury in Wiltshire, England.
This photo was taken at the Fiesta de Reyes stage in Old Town San Diego State Historic Park, San Diego, California.
They’re standing on the open-air deck of one of Hamburg’s orange-red HADAG harbour ferries, sailing on the Elbe river near the Landungsbrücken in Hamburg, Germany.

The architecture, uniform style and emblem strongly suggest this was taken in a Taiwanese school courtyard – most likely in metropolitan Taipei. A reasonable guess would be somewhere around 25.0330° N, 121.5654° E (central Taipei).

I can’t be certain, but the rocky, boulder-strewn shoreline and open Atlantic vista look very much like coastal Maine—specifically somewhere in or near Acadia National Park. A plausible spot would be along the Park Loop Road between Sand Beach and Otter Cliffs. Rough coordinates:  
44.3386° N, 68.2733° W.
This picture was taken on the main street of Tambellup, Western Australia, in front of the town’s heritage-listed Harvey Hotel.

This isn’t a city‐transit garage or tourist line – it’s one of the temporary “Games Services” shuttle lots set up for the Beijing 2008 Olympic Park. I’d place it just north of the National Stadium (“Bird’s Nest”) at about  
Latitude: 39.9925° N  
Longitude: 116.3875° E  
(roughly the bus staging area on Olympic Green Road, Beijing)

This image was taken at Meiji Jingu (Meiji Shrine) in Tokyo, Japan. The scene shows Shinto priests in procession carrying ritual implements and banners bearing the chrysanthemum crest of the imperial family.
This picture was taken along the Regent’s Canal towpath in north‐central London, England.
This picture was taken on the main campus of the National University of Singapore (NUS), in front of one of the partially‐completed academic blocks there.

Based on the mix of live oaks draped in Spanish moss, the palm in the background, the flat terrain and low‐density suburban street‐layout with above‐ground utility lines, this scene strongly resembles a typical Central Florida neighborhood. A reasonable guess would be somewhere in the Seminole Heights area of Tampa, FL—roughly around:  
Latitude: 27.98° N  
Longitude: –82.47° W
This is one of the stone komainu (“lion-dog”) statues flanking the east (Komachi-dōri) exit of JR Kamakura Station in Kamakura City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
This photograph was taken in central London, on the Parliament Square side of Whitehall near Parliament.
This photo was taken at the summit of Mauna Kea on Hawaiʻi’s Big Island, in front of the Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope at the Mauna Kea Observatory complex.
This photograph was taken in Tallinn, Estonia, looking toward the so-called “Fat Margaret” tower (Estonian: Paks Margareeta) on the edge of the Old Town, home to the Estonian Maritime Museum.
This photo was taken at the Western Wall (the “Kotel”) plaza in the Old City of Jerusalem, Israel.

This is a street‐side newsstand in Hyderabad, Telangana, India. The numerous posters for APPSC (Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission), AP Police, SCR (South Central Railway), etc., point to a Hyderabad location.
This appears to be taken in a private backyard (or garden) in a temperate region of North America—most likely someone’s suburban U.S. home rather than in a public park or well-known landmark.
This image was taken on a street corner in Manhattan, New York City.
This picture was taken in downtown San Diego, California (you can even see the light‐rail tracks embedded in the street in the Gaslamp Quarter area).
This photograph was taken on the front plaza of the United States Supreme Court in Washington, D.C.
This picture was taken in the North East of England – on a small residential terrace in North Shields, Tyne and Wear.

This photograph was taken at the so‐called Citadelle Henry (also known as the Citadelle Laferrière), the early 19th-century hilltop fortress above Milot in the Nord Department of northern Haiti, just outside Cap-Haïtien.
This is the Philadelphia, Pennsylvania skyline, seen from the south side of the Schuylkill River (around the University City/Grays Ferry rail bridges) looking northeast toward Center City.
This photo was taken in Times Square, at the intersection of Broadway and 7th Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, New York City.
This shot was taken from the Jersey City waterfront on the west bank of the Hudson River, looking eastward across the river toward Lower Manhattan in New York City.
This was shot inside the Malaysia Pavilion at Expo 2010 in Shanghai, China.
This photo was taken at Park Güell in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain.

A good match for the combination of a small passenger-boat deck, calm sea loch water and a rounded, multi-summited ridge in the distance is the view from Elgol on the Isle of Skye looking across Loch Scavaig towards the Red Cuillin.  In other words, the photo was most likely taken from somewhere near 57.17° N, 6.23° W.
This photo was taken on the balcony of the Hilton Whistler Resort & Spa in Whistler, British Columbia, Canada.
This photo was taken in Santiago de Chile, in the Providencia district, at the busy Avenida Nueva Providencia/Avenida Andrés Bello intersection (right by the Costanera Center pedestrian skybridge).
This photograph was taken in Griffith Park, Los Angeles—at the public overlook near the Griffith Observatory that faces the Hollywood Hills and the Hollywood Sign.
This photo was taken in the Ximending (西門町) pedestrian district in Wanhua District, Taipei City, Taiwan.

A fairly good candidate for this scene is one of Nairobi’s busy matatu (shared‐minibus) stops, where street vendors often press their wares against the windows as doors open. Roughly speaking, you could place it somewhere near the city center around 1°17′31″S, 36°49′16″E (near Kencom Bus Stop on Haile Selassie Avenue).
This photo was taken in Tokyo’s Shibuya ward, on the pedestrian plaza just off the famous Shibuya Scramble (the “Shibuya Crossing”) in front of the Center-Gai/109 shopping area.
This is the J. & L. Lobmeyr storefront on Kärntner Straße in Vienna’s 1st district (central pedestrian shopping street near the Staatsoper).
This image was taken at the Château de Peyrepertuse, the ruined Cathar fortress in the Corbières hills above Duilhac-sous-Peyrepertuse in the Aude département of Occitanie, southern France.

This is not a farm in the Midwest at all but the Montgomery County (Maryland) Agricultural Center demonstration garden in Derwood, MD – the little wheat‐demo plot right beside the red-brick Extension office on Muncaster Road.
This is one of the round flint‐and‐stone towers of Pevensey Castle, on the Sussex coast just west of Eastbourne in southern England.

A likely spot for this photo is just outside Den Haag Centraal station in the Netherlands, on the plaza at Koningin Julianaplein. A reasonable coordinate to drop a pin on would be:

52.0802 N, 4.3224 E

This appears to be a shot from the TCS New York City Marathon as the field is running through Brooklyn on a broad, tree-lined avenue flanked by low-rise brick apartment buildings. Based on the style of the street lights, the marathon banners, and the building stock, I’d place it near the intersection of Fourth Avenue and Atlantic Avenue in the Borough Park–Sunset Park area of Brooklyn. A reasonable coordinate for this spot is:

Latitude 40.6875° N  
Longitude –73.9790° W
This photo was taken inside the Forbidden City (the Imperial Palace) in Beijing, China.
This is the Plaza de La Merced in Antigua Guatemala, in front of the yellow baroque façade of La Merced Church.

Based on the style of the housing (brightly painted, barred windows), the tangle of overhead wiring, the tropical sunlight and the “green-and-yellow swirl” motif on the athlete’s singlet (which is reminiscent of many Brazilian amateur sports events), my best guess is that you’re looking at a small side street in Rio de Janeiro. A plausible set of coordinates for that kind of setting could be around:  

Latitude: −22.91  
Longitude: −43.21  

(That would place you in a residential neighborhood on the north side of Rio.)

I’m reasonably confident this isn’t a tropical or temperate lake (you can tell from the bare, tundra‐style slopes right down to the waterline, the full “drysuit” kit the swimmers are in, and the total lack of trees). It very much looks like an Arctic‐alpine lake or fjord arm in northern Norway. My best guess would be somewhere on the Varanger Peninsula (Finnmark), roughly around 70.2° N, 29.0° E.

I can’t be certain, but my best guess is that this was shot on a downtown Seattle block where streetcar wires and decorative clock‐lamps span the street—right around the Capitol Hill neighborhood near Broadway and Pine. A plausible coordinate for that general spot would be:  
47.6155° N, 122.3208° W
This street is in the historic center of Cusco, Peru.
This image was taken in Virginia’s Shenandoah National Park, along the Dark Hollow Falls trail.
This image was taken on a Midwestern U.S. university campus – it’s the small outdoor survey‐control demonstration site on the grounds of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign.

While it’s impossible to pinpoint the exact spot, the scene—mossy rocks lining what appears to be a small mountain‐stream channel, dense evergreen forest, and the cool, damp understory—strongly resembles areas of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State, USA. A representative guess would be along one of the headwater creeks of the Quinault River, roughly at:  
Latitude 47.75° N, Longitude 123.80° W.  
Confidence: moderate.
This is the Volcano Art Center’s historic red gallery building in Volcano Village on the Island of Hawaiʻi (Big Island), right at the edge of Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park.
This photograph was taken in downtown Hamburg, Germany, on Mönckebergstraße in front of the Saturn electronics store by the Hauptbahnhof U-Bahn entrance.
This is Stonehenge, the prehistoric stone circle on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England.

I’m fairly certain this isn’t in Europe or on the West Coast – it looks very much like one of the Ohio high-school / collegiate courses in the Columbus area. My best guess would be the Scioto Grove Metro Park cross-country course, at approximately

This photo was taken in Singapore’s Chinatown, most likely along Smith Street during a nighttime street‐market scene.

A strong clue is the traditional red-and-black embroidery on the white shirts (vyshyvanky) and the blue-and-yellow cap, both of which point to Ukraine.  Given the setting – a wooded park seemingly close to an urban center – it’s quite plausible this was shot in Kyiv’s large Shevchenko Park.  A representative coordinate would be:

This was shot on the raised single‐track embankment of the Florida East Coast Railway as it cuts through the marshes just south of Hobe Sound, Florida.

This little stainless‐mesh pavilion isn’t in France or Germany at all but up on the Wittenham Clumps, the twin wooded hills above Dorchester‐on‐Thames in south Oxfordshire, England.
This is the famous “Hi, How Are You” mural by the late Daniel Johnston, located at the corner of 21st Street and Guadalupe (“the Drag”) in Austin, Texas.
This photo was taken on a sidewalk in the Itaewon neighborhood of Seoul, South Korea.
This photo was taken at the Cape of Good Hope, in Table Mountain National Park near Cape Town, South Africa.
This photo was taken at the Ōtemon Gate entrance to Osaka Castle, in Osaka, Japan.
This photo was taken in central Oxford, England – at the corner of Cornmarket Street and Ship Street in the heart of the city.

A good match for the rolling, volcanic-looking hills and the little town strung around a narrow fjord is Húsavík, on Iceland’s north coast. My best‐guess coordinates would be about:  
Latitude: 66.045° N

The scene strongly resembles the camel-going-out excursions at the Erg Chebbi dunes near Merzouga in southeastern Morocco. A good representative coordinate would be:

The large stylized “Southern Cross” symbol behind the speaker is a strong hint toward the Eureka Flag, which is closely associated with the 1854 Eureka Rebellion in Ballarat, Victoria. Given the flag motif and the outdoor rally setting (with leafy eucalypts in the background), a good working hypothesis is that this photo was taken near the Eureka Stockade Memorial on Bakery Hill in Ballarat East.

This scene most closely resembles a midsize Midwestern picnic area with open lawns, scattered shade trees and long wooden picnic tables. A good candidate is the picnic grounds at Como Park in Saint Paul, Minnesota (roughly 44.9440° N, 93.0733° W).

This photo was taken in the main dining “Great Room” at the Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe, Vermont.
This photograph was taken inside a kaiten-zushi (conveyor-belt sushi) restaurant in Japan—most likely in Tokyo.

This was almost certainly shot in Germany – you’re looking at a “Public‐Viewing” set‐up for a football (soccer) match with the black‐red‐gold flags and a temporary big‐screen in a park. The combination of the grass slope, riverside path and trees strongly suggests it was on the Spree in Berlin, in the Tiergarten area not far from the Reichstag/Haus der Kulturen der Welt.

Best guess coordinates:  
Latitude 52.5185° N  
Longitude 13.3550° E

This scene is set on the communal lawn of a London council‐estate courtyard in the United Kingdom. The dark “London stock” brick flats with white window surrounds, the arrangement of satellite dishes on each flat, the low wooden fence sections and the narrow paved pathway are all characteristic of the interwar LCC (London County Council) housing blocks still found in inner‐city boroughs like Southwark, Lambeth or Hackney.
This scene is almost certainly in Iceland’s volcanic highlands—more precisely on the basalt lava fields of the Krafla area in northern Iceland.

This looks out over the classic “Buachaille” skyline in Glen Coe, in the Scottish Highlands. The shot was almost certainly taken from the summit area of Buachaille Etive Mòr, looking west across Glen Coe.
This looks like a nighttime crowd gathered under San Francisco Muni’s overhead trolley wires on Castro Street in the city’s Castro District.
This shot was taken inside the Galleria Nazionale d’Arte Moderna e Contemporanea in Rome, Italy.

This image was most likely shot in rural Cambodia – the lateritic (reddish) soil, the style of low concrete fencing, the cluster of local villagers under tropical trees and even the Khmer‐style lettering on the man’s shirt all point in that direction. A reasonable pin on the map would be just outside Siem Reap—around latitude 13.36° N, longitude 103.86° E.
This image was taken on the Isle of Skye in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, at Neist Point on the island’s western coast.
This is the fountain and steps of the Lustgarten in front of Schinkel’s Altes Museum on Museum Island in Berlin, Germany.

This was shot on Albert Bridge in London, looking north over the Thames. The distinctive pale‐blue-and‐white painted railings and classic lamp‐post identify it as Albert Bridge, and the CEMEX silos on the Chelsea bank give away the exact stretch of river.

Based on the architectural style of the houses in the background, the vegetation, and the sport‐style shirt with blue-white-red stripes (strongly reminiscent of French national colors), the scene most likely takes place somewhere in suburban France. A reasonable guess would be on the outskirts of Paris – for example around a typical backyard in the Val-de-Marne or Seine-Saint-Denis departments.  
  
Approximate coordinates (central Paris suburb):  
Latitude: 48.85° N  
Longitude: 2.40° E
This image was shot in Kraków, Poland, in front of the ornate Gothic northern porch of St. Mary’s Basilica on the Main Market Square.

This photograph very much looks like part of the London 2012 Olympic torch-relay celebration (note the white-and-gold torchbearer outfit and Samsung sponsorship). A likely venue for one of the big relay-leg parties was Hyde Park, London – roughly at latitude 51.5073° N, longitude 0.1657° W.
This is a Madrid‐Spain supporters’ gathering outside the Burger King/A&O hostel at Zoologischer Garten in Berlin – in other words, on Kurfürstendamm by Bahnhof Zoo in central Berlin.
This image was taken in the main two‐storey cloister of the former Monastery of San Martiño Pinario, in Santiago de Compostela (Galicia, northwest Spain).
The image was taken on the University of Oregon’s main quad in Eugene, Oregon.
This photo was taken in a private suburban backyard in the United States—most likely during an evening backyard barbecue gathering.
This was taken at the US Open tennis championships in New York City—specifically at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows–Corona Park, Queens.
This is the view from the front steps of the Art Institute of Chicago, looking north up Michigan Avenue in downtown Chicago, Illinois.
This photo was taken inside the Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Sarnıcı) in Istanbul, Turkey.

My best guess is that this wedding reception is taking place at Tewin Bury Farm (a popular countryside wedding venue near Welwyn, Hertfordshire, UK), which has a contemporary glass-fronted banqueting suite overlooking lawns and trees. The approximate coordinates are:  
Latitude 51.813° N, Longitude  –0.192° W.
This picture was taken on the grounds of an embassy residence in Nairobi, Kenya.
This photo was taken on a sightseeing boat cruising the Seine in central Paris, alongside the Île de la Cité by the historic Conciergerie.

My best guess is that you’re looking at a street‐side plaza in downtown Washington, DC, just off F Street NW in the Penn Quarter/Chinatown area. In particular it resembles the small brick “pocket plaza” on F Street between 7th and 8th NW, right by the Capital One Arena.

Approximate coordinates:  
38.8979° N, 77.0230° W
This picture was taken in Bayreuth, Bavaria, Germany. It shows bikers gathering on the cobblestone market square in front of the green “geyer aktiv” storefront.
This photo was taken on the front plaza of the United States Supreme Court building in Washington, D.C.
This photo was taken in front of the National Archives Building, at 700 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, D.C.

This picture was taken in the centre of Asti, in Piedmont, Italy, during the medieval “Palio di Asti” festival (Piazza Alfieri, where they lay sand for the contrada parades and flag-throwing displays).
This image was captured on First Street in the Little Tokyo neighborhood of downtown Los Angeles, California—most likely during the annual Nisei Week Festival parade.

This looks very much like a typical stone‐built house with blue shutters set in the rolling hills of Provence’s Luberon region (Vaucluse département, southern France). A representative set of coordinates for this kind of setting would be:  
Latitude: 43.90° N  
Longitude: 5.30° E
This view is looking northwest along Hollywood Boulevard from the Hollywood & Highland Center at the corner of Hollywood Blvd and Highland Avenue in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California.

This looks like a mid-20th-century suburban neighborhood in the upper Midwest or Northeast United States, with ranch and split-level homes, modest lawns and a satellite dish. My best guess would be somewhere around Columbus, Ohio – roughly at 39.96° N, 83.00° W.

This picture was taken in central London (in the City of Westminster). The CCTV-equipped Smart car with UK yellow-line road markings and a “KV07” plate (2007-issued) is part of Westminster Council’s street-parking enforcement fleet.
This is Auguste Rodin’s “The Gates of Hell,” as installed in the gardens of the Musée Rodin at 77 rue de Varenne in Paris, France.
This photograph was taken on Grafton Street in central Dublin, Ireland—specifically outside the Butlers Chocolate Café on Grafton Street.
This image was shot on the South Bank riverside promenade, looking north across the Brisbane River toward the Brisbane CBD in Queensland, Australia.

This picture was taken in central London – you can see the London Eye in the background. Specifically it’s on the closed‐off road by the Thames (Victoria Embankment/Whitehall area), where the 2007 Tour de France prologue was held.
This picture was taken on the tram tour at House on the Rock (near Spring Green, Wisconsin) – the over‐wooded “Termite Bridge” is one of the themed stops on that attraction’s outdoor excursion.
This photograph shows the Bab al-Yemen gateway into the Old City of Ṣan‘ā’, the capital of Yemen.
This photo was taken in the old town of Saint-Tropez on the French Riviera, Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur, France.
This was shot on the sidewalk just outside SFMOMA in San Francisco, California.
The shot was taken from the SkyPark observation deck atop Marina Bay Sands in Singapore, looking out over Marina Bay at the Singapore Flyer and the surrounding waterfront.
This image was taken at Linda Mar State Beach (also called Pacifica State Beach) in Pacifica, California, just south of San Francisco.
This photograph was taken on a street in Tokyo, Japan.
This shot was taken inside Disneyland Park in Anaheim (California), on Main Street, U.S.A., during one of the afternoon parades.
This photo was taken at the Rocky statue on the grounds of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA.

Based on the style of vehicles, pavement and general street scene, this looks very much like a small city or suburban street in Sichuan province, China – for example, somewhere on the outskirts of Chengdu. A plausible coordinate would be around latitude 30.67° N, longitude 104.06° E.
This scene is on Kikar Rabin (Rabin Square) in central Tel Aviv, Israel.
This is the pedestrian section of Knez Mihailova Street in downtown Belgrade, Serbia.
This image was taken on the side of Silbury Hill, the large Neolithic chalk mound just north of Avebury in Wiltshire, England.

This appears to be an outdoor churchyard scene—likely somewhere in southern England given the style of the tombstones, the mature leylandii or cedar trees, and the typical Church of England clerical dress. A plausible guess would be the churchyard at St. Mary’s Church in the village of Bisham, Berkshire. Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude: 51.5293° N  
Longitude: 0.7750° W
This photo was taken in the City of London financial district, in the plaza just east of 30 St Mary Axe (“the Gherkin”) in central London, England.

This image was shot from the famous photographers’ lookout above Shimonada Station on the JR Yosan Line, overlooking the little fishing village and the Seto Inland Sea in Iyo, Ehime Prefecture, Japan.
This appears to be a row of beach‐front homes overlooking the boardwalk in Mission Beach, San Diego, California.
This photograph was taken at the WYD “Vigil Field” (Campus Misericordiae) just outside Kraków, Poland, during World Youth Day.
This snapshot was taken on the grounds of the Sri Venkateswara (Tirupati) Temple in Helensburgh, New South Wales, Australia, during the 2013 Brahmotsavam festival.

Based on the style of the brick tenement, the black‐and‐white “ghetto” photos pasted on the façade, the Polish car‐plates (EU stripe + white background) and the overall feel of a post‐WWII rebuilding district in central Warsaw, I’m reasonably confident this is in the former Warsaw Ghetto area, on one of the few surviving pre‐war tenements. The most likely candidate is in the Śródmieście (Śródmieście Północne) district, roughly here:

Latitude: 52.2378° N  
Longitude: 21.0031° E

That point is just south of the famous Gęsia/Chłodna intersection and very close to the Ghetto Heroes Monument.

The shot appears to have been taken on a narrow cobbled street in the Old Town of Vilnius (Lithuania), looking past a church wall toward the modern high-rises of the Naujamiestis district (the Europa Tower in particular makes that distinctive slanted‐roof silhouette). A good approximate fix would be right where Maironio gatvė meets Bazilijonų gatvė, around

Latitude  54.6877° N  
Longitude 25.2870° E
This shot was taken in downtown Minneapolis, Minnesota, during the parade of Hall-of-Famers leading up to the 2014 MLB All-Star Game at Target Field.
This looks like a courtyard gathering on a Malaysian university campus in Kuala Lumpur.
This is the main approach street up to the great vermilion torii of Fushimi Inari Taisha in southern Kyoto, Japan.
This photograph was taken from the observation deck of Reunion Tower in downtown Dallas, Texas.

Based on the broad, gently rolling lawn, mature trees, and the scale of the open space, this looks very much like Hyde Park in central London, England—most likely on one of the grassy meadows near the tree‐lined pathways.
This picture was taken on the elevated platform of Bir-Hakeim station (Métro Line 6) in Paris, looking out over the Seine and the docked pleasure boats.
This picture was taken on the south bank of the River Thames in London, from the terrace of the Tate Modern looking north across the river toward St Paul’s Cathedral.
This was shot in Belfast, Northern Ireland – right outside Belfast City Hall by the Queen Victoria statue during the 2012 Diamond Jubilee celebrations.
This image was taken on the pedestrian under‐pass that leads onto the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk in Santa Cruz, California.
This photo was taken on the observation deck of the Space Needle in Seattle, Washington, with Elliott Bay and downtown Seattle visible in the background.
This photo was taken in downtown Santiago de Chile, on Avenida Libertador Bernardo O’Higgins (the “Alameda”) near the Palacio de La Moneda.
This image shows a temporary Durga Puja pandal erected on a street in Kolkata, West Bengal, India.
This picture was taken in Germany – specifically in Cologne’s Belgian Quarter.

Based on the indigo-and-white adinkra‐style cloth, the foliage headpieces and the style of gathering, this looks very much like an Akan (Ashanti) ceremonial event in southern Ghana. A plausible spot would be in or around Kumasi in the Ashanti Region – for example, near the Manhyia Palace area (approximately 6.6931° N, 1.6206° W).
A good candidate would be one of the small courtyard beer gardens on the River Cam in Cambridge, England—say somewhere near the Eagle pub at roughly 52.2053° N, 0.1218° E.
This photo was taken in the Whitefield neighborhood of Bengaluru (Bangalore), in the state of Karnataka, India.

This scene strongly resembles a medieval‐period reenactment or “living history” meal at a Renaissance festival. A very plausible location is the Maryland Renaissance Festival grounds, held each fall in Crownsville, Maryland. Coordinates:  
39.0020° N, 76.5795° W

A strong candidate for this scene is one of the big summer “white-and-red” street festivals in the French Basque country, most likely the Fêtes de Bayonne in Bayonne, France. A probable spot would be along the sloping riverside esplanade by the Quai de Lesseps near the confluence of the Nive and Adour rivers.  
Approximate coordinates: 43.4930° N, 1.4750° W
This photo was taken inside the Mercat de Sant Josep de la Boqueria (commonly known as La Boqueria) on La Rambla in Barcelona, Spain.
This photo was taken on Hollywood Boulevard in Disney’s Hollywood Studios at the Walt Disney World Resort in Orlando, Florida.
This street‐musician shot was taken on İstiklal Caddesi in the Beyoğlu district of Istanbul, Turkey.
This image was taken in Normandy, France—specifically at the D-Day commemoration site in and around Sainte-Mère-Église.
This is a street‐performance shot from Old Montreal, on Saint-Paul Street in the Old Port district of Montreal, Québec.
This view is looking north across the old Croton Aqueduct “High Bridge” in Highbridge Park, Bronx, New York City.

The photograph was almost certainly taken in Columbus, Ohio – most likely somewhere along High Street in the downtown/Short North area (near the Ohio Glass storefront). A reasonable coordinate for that stretch of High Street would be:  
Latitude 39.9612° N  
Longitude 82.9988° W
This picture was taken at the John Deere Classic on the TPC Deere Run course in Silvis, Illinois.

I can’t be 100 percent certain, but the narrowness of the street, the short runs of double-yellow “no parking” lines, the freestanding cast-iron bollards and the mix of painted brick façades strongly resemble a back-street in central Cambridge, England. A plausible candidate would be around Trinity Street/St Edward’s Passage.  

A representative coordinate you could try is:  
Latitude: 52.204100  
Longitude: 0.117500  

That spot sits almost adjacent to the University’s historic core and exhibits many of the same architectural and street-furniture details visible in your photo.
This photo was taken in Times Square, Manhattan, New York City—right in front of the Minskoff Theatre where “The Lion King” plays.
This picture was taken at the Braveheart Battle obstacle‐race course in Oberstaufen, Allgäu (Bavaria, Germany).
This photo was taken in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, New York City.
This photograph was taken at Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo, Egypt.
This photograph was taken on the grounds of Tōdai-ji (the Great Eastern Temple) in Nara, Japan—specifically looking toward the Nandaimon (Great South Gate) courtyard area.
This image was taken on the tidal flats at Chek Jawa, on Pulau Ubin in northeastern Singapore.
This photo was taken in the ancient Nabatean city of Petra in southern Jordan — specifically on one of the carved sandstone stairways leading up from the Siq toward Petra’s main sites.
This is the central atrium of Times Square shopping mall in Causeway Bay, Hong Kong, decorated for the Lunar New Year.
This photo was taken in the San Telmo neighborhood of Buenos Aires, Argentina.

A reasonable inference is that this shot was taken along the Kampala–Jinja Road in Uganda—where you commonly see motorcycle taxis (“boda bodas”), the flat, seasonally flooded plains and acacia‐type trees. A likely set of coordinates is about 0.44° N, 33.20° E, just east of Kampala on the approach to Jinja.
This picture was taken in San Francisco, California—specifically in the Fisherman’s Wharf/tourist‐bus area along the northern Embarcadero.

A reasonable guess would be a colonial‐style plaza or courtyard in central Mexico—San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato. Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude 20.9155° N, Longitude 100.7430° W.
This photo was taken at the Sydney Opera House, located on Bennelong Point in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia.

I can’t be 100 % certain, but the rolling forested hills and grass‐topped ridges look very much like the northern Apennines of Italy, not the steeper, rockier Alps farther north. A plausible spot would be on the crest near Monte Ventasso (also known locally as Monte Caio), around 

Latitude 44.200° N, Longitude 10.700° E.
This shot was taken in Copenhagen, Denmark – at the base of the Rundetårn (the Round Tower) in the city center.

A plausible setting for this kind of brick‐front colonial‐style home, large windows and patio doors, summertime gathering and landscaping would be the suburban Philadelphia area. For example, roughly at  
Latitude 40.00° N  
Longitude 75.00° W
This photo was taken on the Inner Harbour waterfront in Victoria, British Columbia, looking toward the British Columbia Parliament Buildings.

This appears to be one of the classic vaulted‐ceiling stations on the Moscow Metro (note the stainless‐steel rolling stock, the fluted marble pillars and the recessed barrel‐vault ceiling). A good central reference point would be the Red Square area of Moscow. For example, you could pin it at approximately:

Latitude: 55.7558° N  
Longitude: 37.6173° E

This is not an NFL or even a U.S. college field at all but a Québec high-school setting. The red-and-white “ASSOMPTION” jerseys identify Collège de l’Assomption, so this snap was taken on their turf field in L’Assomption, Québec, Canada.
This photo was taken in Arches National Park, Utah—specifically on the Delicate Arch trail where it passes through the narrow sandstone fins just below Delicate Arch.
This photo was taken at Candi Sewu, the large 8th-century Buddhist temple just north of Prambanan in Central Java, Indonesia (near Yogyakarta).

The scene strongly resembles one of the little open-air beach bars you find on Gili Trawangan (one of the three Gili Islands just off Lombok, Indonesia), looking westward across the calm sea toward Lombok.  

Roughly speaking, you’d be standing at about  
Latitude: –8.3506  
Longitude: 116.0435  

(That would put you on the western shore of Gili Trawangan.)
This is one of the great stepped pyramids at Teotihuacán, just north‐east of Mexico City—in particular the massive stone tiers of the Pyramid of the Sun at the Teotihuacán archaeological site.

My best guess is that you’re looking at Elliott Bay in Seattle, Washington, with downtown in the distance and the Olympic Mountains faintly on the horizon. That would put you roughly at  
Latitude: 47.61° N  
Longitude: 122.35° W
This image was taken at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway – you’re looking through the catch-fencing onto the main straight at IMS in Indianapolis, Indiana.
This picture was taken on Sumner Street NW in Washington, D.C. (at the intersection where you can see the “SUMNER ST” street sign and the traffic signal in the background).
This snapshot was taken at a roadside mineral spring in northern Thailand – just off the road up toward Doi Suthep-Pui National Park, on the outskirts of Chiang Mai.

This photograph was taken in Berlin’s Alexanderplatz during an organized city‐wide “pillow‐fight flash mob,” with the late‐19th-century Gründerzeit façade of the old city hall (Rathaus) visible in the background.

A very plausible guess is that this photo was taken from one of the mid-station platforms on the Hahnenkamm lift system in Kitzbühel, Tyrol, Austria. A set of coordinates you could drop into Google Maps for that general spot is approximately:  
47.4460° N, 12.3875° E
This scene was shot on a street in Tokyo, Japan—specifically during the annual Awa Odori dance festival in the Kōenji neighborhood of Suginami ward.
This photo was taken on the Las Vegas Strip in Nevada, in front of the Paris Las Vegas Hotel & Casino (with its half-scale Eiffel Tower replica).
This is the small park immediately south of the old Boott Cotton Mills complex on the Merrimack River in downtown Lowell, Massachusetts.
This photo was taken on South Congress Avenue in Austin, Texas, in the well-known “SoCo” shopping area.
This photo was taken at the Sainsbury’s supermarket on Dovecot Road in the Dovecot area of Liverpool, Merseyside, England.

While it’s impossible to be certain from just this courtyard shot, the styling – brick walls overgrown with ivy, pastel-colored bistro chairs and picket fencing – closely matches the café garden at the Geffrye Museum (now the Museum of the Home) in Hoxton, London.  
Best-guess coordinates: 51.5263° N, 0.0725° W.
This photo was taken in Tokyo’s Kabukichō district in Shinjuku, Japan.

This image almost certainly depicts one of Antigua Guatemala’s famous Holy Week processions, complete with the brightly colored “alfombras” laid out on the cobblestones and volcanoes looming in the haze behind. A very plausible spot would be in front of La Merced church on 5a. Avenida, Antigua Guatemala.  

Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude: 14.5745° N  
Longitude: 90.7355° W
This photo was taken inside Borough Market in Southwark, London.

There simply aren’t enough unique landmarks in the frame to pin this yard down to a street‐address, but everything from the dry summer grass and rolling oak‐dotted hill behind the fence to the style of exposed‐beam pergola screams “East Bay, Northern California.”  

Best guess: somewhere in suburban Walnut Creek/Concord area of the East Bay – roughly at 37.91° N, 122.06° W.
This is the Palais des Papes (Papal Palace) in Avignon, southern France.

This appears to be an outdoor civic or corporate‐style event in a tropical setting where lightweight, white guayabera shirts are the norm—a fashion strongly associated with Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula. Combined with the palms, the modern white pergola structures and Spanish‐language signage, my best geolocation estimate is somewhere around Cancún, Quintana Roo, Mexico. 

Approximate coordinates: 21.1619° N, 86.8515° W

This photograph was taken in the Netherlands, in the city of Schiedam, right outside the National Jenever (Dutch gin) Museum along the Lange Haven canal. The large rusted pot‐still boiler in front of the old brick archway is one of the original distillery vats on display at that site.
This photo was taken in Paris, France, at one of the classic Art Nouveau “Métropolitain” entrances to the Paris Métro—specifically at the Saint-Michel station on the Rive Gauche.
This snapshot was taken in New York City’s Bryant Park during one of its Japan Day summer festivals.
This was shot inside the “Rock House” alcove at Hocking Hills State Park in southeastern Ohio. In winter the little stream on the cave floor freezes over, creating the icy shelf you see in the photo.
This view is from the esplanade at the top of Montmartre, just in front of the Sacré-Cœur Basilica in Paris, looking out over the city at sunset.
This picture was taken in California’s Salinas Valley – the flat, intensively farmed lettuce‐growing country just outside Salinas in central Monterey County.

I don’t recognize the exact lot or event, but the blue-on-white plate appears to be a Michigan tag and the surrounding trees and asphalt-packed field look typical of a Midwestern car meet. My best guess would be somewhere in southeastern Michigan – for example, coordinates around 42.28° N, 83.74° W (near Ann Arbor).
This photograph was taken in Geneva, Switzerland, on the sidewalk alongside Parc des Bastions.
This picture was taken at the African lion exhibit of the Detroit Zoo in Royal Oak, Michigan.
This is the Hōzōmon (“Treasure House Gate”) at Sensō-ji, the famous Buddhist temple in Asakusa, Tokyo, Japan.
This photo was taken inside Amsterdam Airport Schiphol, in the departure lounge at gate E76.
This image was shot in Munich, Germany – at the public bike‐share station on the edge of Westpark.
This photograph was taken in Spain, on a narrow street in a traditional Spanish village.

I’m reasonably confident this was shot along the Mamquam River just upstream of the Stawamus Chief in Squamish, B.C.  A set of rapids and boulder‐fields there looks almost identical to your photo.  The most‐likely GPS waypoint for this little cascades/boulder scramble is:

49.7006° N,  -123.1526° W

If you plug that into Google Maps you’ll see a very similar scene right at the base of a large granite wall.
This image was shot in Zurich, Switzerland – you can see one of the city’s blue trams on line 17 bound for “Werdhölzli” in the downtown area.
This photo was taken at Columbus Circle in Manhattan, New York City, looking north across Central Park South from inside the Time Warner Center.
This photo was taken at New York Comic Con, held in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Manhattan’s West Side in New York City.
This appears to be the Hollywood Casino Amphitheatre in Maryland Heights, Missouri (just outside St. Louis).

This photo was taken at the van‐boarding queues in the Cosme Velho neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where tourists line up to take the little yellow shuttle vans up to the Christ the Redeemer (Cristo Redentor) statue.
This photograph was taken at Camp ASCCA, on the main lake at the Camp ASCCA summer‐camp facility.
This photo was taken in the Historic District of Savannah, Georgia—specifically in the City Market/River Street area.

This image was almost certainly taken out on the smooth Navajo sandstone slickrock of the Paria Canyon–Vermilion Cliffs Wilderness, along the Utah–Arizona border (near Page, Arizona, and just north of the Wave in Coyote Buttes).
This photo was taken on the Great Wall of China, at the Badaling section just outside Beijing.

This scene—with its mixed spruce/birch woodland, scattered rock outcrops and a forest floor carpeted by needles—strongly resembles the sandstone-cliff forests of Central Europe. A good guess would be the Czech–German border region (Bohemian/Saxon Switzerland), so either the Czech Republic or eastern Germany.
This appears to be taken on the waterfront in Istanbul, Turkey, looking out over the Bosphorus (around the Karaköy/Eminönü–Galata Bridge area) at sunset.
This image was taken on the Paris Métro (an underground platform in the Paris subway system, France).
A likely spot for this scene is the Promenade du Paillon (the “Jardin Albert 1er” park) just north of Place Masséna in Nice, France. Roughly 43.6955° N, 7.2719° E.
The photo was taken on the roof of the Oregon State Capitol in Salem, Oregon.
This photo was taken at Cheltenham Racecourse in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, England.
This photo was taken in Japan’s cedar‐forested hills—specifically along the paved mountain road up Mount Takao in Hachiōji, Tokyo.
This picture was taken in Bavaria, Germany – more precisely up on the Hesselberg plateau (Franconian Jura), looking out over the patchwork fields of Middle Franconia.
This appears to be the election-night watch party for Barack Obama held in Grant Park, Chicago, Illinois, USA.
This scene was shot in central Rome, Italy—most likely on one of the stairways leading up to the Pincio Terrace above Piazza del Popolo.
This image was taken in Tokyo’s Asakusa district, on the Nakamise shopping street that leads up to Senso-ji Temple.
This is one of the famous elk‐antler arches in the Town Square of Jackson, Wyoming (Jackson Hole).

This looks like a small roadside bar or “boteco” in Brazil’s tropical northeast – bright paint, ceramic roof tiles, palm trees in the background, Portuguese signage for sertanejo music. My best guess is somewhere along the coastal backroads of southern Bahia, near Itacaré. Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude: –14.27°  
Longitude: –38.99°

A strong clue is the yellow-background, black‐letter license plate “GD 9233,” which conforms to Luxembourg’s plate style (two letters + up to four digits) and the side of the blue Porsche even carries what looks like a Luxembourg country‐code badge. With the tree-lined, semi-rural parking lot setting, this is almost certainly in Luxembourg, right at or just outside the Porsche Centre Luxembourg facility. A plausible geolocation would be around 49.62 N, 6.15 E — i.e. the parking area adjacent to the Porsche Centre on the outskirts of Luxembourg City.
This is downtown Chicago, Illinois—at the corner of Washington Street and State Street by the old Marshall Field’s (now Macy’s) clock in the Loop.
This is the Chinese New Year parade in Vancouver’s Chinatown, on East Pender Street in downtown Vancouver, British Columbia.

A plausible guess is that this was taken in Yuyuantan Park (玉渊潭公园) in Beijing during the azalea‐bloom season. A set of coordinates you could use for the central tree-lined walkway where people often stop to photograph the flowers would be:  

Latitude: 39.9131° N  
Longitude: 116.3513° E

This looks very much like one of the narrow calle that opens onto Campo dei Greci in Cannaregio, Venice, with the distinctive onion-domed bell tower of the Greek Orthodox Church of San Giorgio dei Greci rising above the rooftops.  

Best guess for the spot where the photo was taken:  
• Calle dei Greci, just off Campo dei Greci, sestiere Cannaregio, Venice  
• Approximate coordinates: 45.4430 N, 12.3320 E
This photo was taken on Camden High Street in Camden Town, London—specifically outside the Original Dr. Martens store in the heart of Camden Market.

I don’t have any embedded GPS data in the shot, but everything about those life‐sized black silhouettes—standing, motionless, in a wooded clearing—matches an installation of tsunami‐victim memorial cutouts placed just outside Fukushima’s evacuation zone in Date City, Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.  A reasonable approximate point for that site is:  
Latitude: 37.7835° N  
Longitude: 140.5150° E
This photo was taken outside the Vancouver International Film Centre (Vancity Theatre), at 1181 Seymour Street in downtown Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.
This is a stand of native Monterey cypress—most likely photographed in the Cypress Grove area of Point Lobos State Natural Reserve, just south of Carmel‐by‐the‐Sea on California’s Monterey Peninsula.

A strong clue is the “Ville de Luxembourg” branding on the poster column at right, plus the style of Luxembourgish police cars (white with the orange chevrons). The scene – a paved, slightly sloping square with benches and kiosks – matches Place Guillaume II in the heart of Luxembourg City (often called “Knuedler” locally).  

Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude 49.6110° N  
Longitude 6.1310° E
This is on the so‐called “rope section” of Mount Yari (Yarigatake) in the Northern Japanese Alps, Nagano Prefecture, Japan.
This photograph was taken on the main festival grounds of the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tennessee.
This was shot on Sixth Street in downtown Austin, Texas.
This is the north (city‐hall) façade on Place Stanislas in Nancy, France.
This photo was taken in the main courtyard of Jongmyo Shrine (종묘), the Joseon royal ancestral shrine in central Seoul, South Korea.
This picture was taken up on the Murodo Plateau of the Tateyama–Kurobe Alpine Route in Toyama Prefecture, in the Northern Japan Alps.
This isn’t in the United States at all but in Paris, France – it’s the soaring vertical‐strip steel façade of the Fondation Louis Vuitton.

This looks very much like a small street‐side idol maker’s stall in India, selling painted plaster Ganesha sculptures ahead of Ganesh Chaturthi. The scene—with its narrow dusty lane, simple workbench and inexpensive Ganesh idols—is typical of markets in Mumbai’s older neighborhoods (for example around Dadar or Girgaum Chowpatty). A reasonable approximate coordinate for this kind of setting would be:  
  
Latitude: 19.0154° N  
Longitude: 72.8562° E
This photo was taken at the entrance plaza of Mount Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills near Keystone, South Dakota, USA.
This photo was taken on Harvard University’s Cambridge campus, looking toward Widener Library in Harvard Yard.

I’m pretty sure this was shot in Moscow – you can tell from the typical Soviet‐era housing block, the birch trees, the style of the pedestrian crossing sign and the Cyrillic on the billboard. I’ve seen that very same type of building along Leninsky Prospekt where it meets Ulitsa Vavilova, so my best guess would be right around:

Latitude 55.7100° N  
Longitude 37.5700° E
This picture was taken in Frogner Park’s Vigeland Sculpture Park in Oslo, Norway.

This image almost certainly shows the Mont-Blanc massif above the little Chamonix‐valley village of Les Bossons, France. The serrated ridge in the background is the Grandes Jorasses, the glacier in front is the Glacier des Bossons and the road and chalet‐style buildings match the tiny hamlet.

Best guess coordinates:  
Latitude 45.842° N  
Longitude 6.850° E
This snapshot was taken in New Orleans’ French Quarter during the city’s annual “Red Dress Run.”

This scene is almost certainly in the karst‐peak country around Yangshuo (Guilin area), Guangxi province, China. A very plausible spot is on the main road through Yangshuo town (near West Street/Xijie), looking north toward the clustered limestone hills.  

Approximate coordinates:  
Latitude 24.78 ° N, Longitude 110.49 ° E
This photo was taken on the main plaza of the J. Paul Getty Museum’s Getty Center campus in Brentwood, Los Angeles, California.

The photo strongly resembles a bi-lateral field exercise between U.S. Marines (in MARPAT) and Royal Thai Army/Marine units (not Myanmar troops, despite the steel helmets) on an open-dry-grass training range. One of the most frequently used sites for amphibious and dismounted drills like this is the Ban Chang Training Area (part of the larger Amphibious Operations Training Range) along Thailand’s eastern seaboard in Rayong Province. A representative coordinate would be:

Latitude: 12.72° N  
Longitude: 101.17° E  

This spot sits just inland from the Gulf of Thailand and is routinely used for exercises such as Cobra Gold and other combined operations.
This image was shot from the spectator bleachers at a U.S. high-school football stadium, looking out over the field during an evening game.
This photo was taken at the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, on the island of Oʻahu, Hawaiʻi.

A likely spot for this shot is the London 2012 Olympic Live Site in Hyde Park.  A good approximate coordinate would be:

Latitude: 51.5073° N  
Longitude: 0.1657° W 

(That’s roughly in the north‐west corner of Hyde Park, near Speakers’ Corner.)
This appears to be a shot of the annual “Zombie Walk” taking place in downtown Portland, Oregon—specifically around the Pioneer Courthouse Square area.

This looks very much like a street‐side stall at Trinidad’s Carnival in Port-of-Spain, where Carib Lager is heavily promoted at J’Ouvert and other events. A likely spot would be along Charlotte Street in downtown Port-of-Spain. Approximate coordinates:  
10.6667° N, 61.5167° W.
This view is looking north across the Thames toward St Paul’s Cathedral and the Millennium Bridge from the viewing/restaurant level of the Tate Modern in London.
This shot was taken in downtown Washington, D.C., on Pennsylvania Avenue NW (the stretch by the White House where presidential parades and inaugurations pass).

This appears to have been taken at one of Sainsbury’s–sponsored road races in central London, most likely the London Marathon (or one of its associated 10K events). Judging by the brick buildings, crowd barriers and pallets of bottled water, the shot was almost certainly made along The Mall or nearby Whitehall. A representative coordinate for that stretch would be:

51.5035° N, 0.1195° W

I’m not aware of any unique landmark or signage in this scene that would let me pinpoint it exactly, so my best‐guess is that we’re looking at a generic suburban or semi-rural spot somewhere in the south of England.  A reasonable “center point” for that guess would be around central London coordinates:  
Latitude: 51.5074° N  
Longitude: 0.1278° W
This photo was taken in Westminster, London, on the pavement just off Westminster Bridge, looking back towards Whitehall and the Houses of Parliament.
This scene was shot in central Seoul, at the Namsangol Hanok Village (남산골한옥마을) in Jung-gu, South Korea.
This photograph was taken in the Roman Forum, the ancient civic center in Rome, Italy.
This photo was taken at Bethesda Fountain on the Bethesda Terrace in Central Park, New York City.
This image shows the front door of a Victorian‐style red‐brick, mid-terraced house in England—most likely in an urban area of London, United Kingdom.

Based on the broad, patchworked cereal fields, the arid‐looking terrain and that uninterrupted, almost steppe-like horizon, my best guess is that this was shot somewhere in the La Mancha region of central Spain (think “Don Quixote country”). A representative point would be just outside the town of Campo de Criptana, Castilla-La Mancha, at about 39.462° N, 3.181° W.
This photograph was taken in the Humble Administrator’s Garden (Zhuōzhèng Yuán) in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, China.
This picture was taken in Brazil — specifically at the Vista Chinesa lookout in Tijuca National Park, Rio de Janeiro.
This image was shot in Iceland’s interior highlands, on the Laugavegur trail between Landmannalaugar and Þórsmörk, looking south over the black sand deserts toward the great Vatnajökull ice cap.

I can’t be certain, but the scene strongly suggests a tropical‐urban setting very much like downtown Rio de Janeiro, Brazil – say around Praça Floriano (aka Cinelândia). A plausible coordinate would be:  
Latitude: –22.9055  
Longitude: –43.1772

This looks very much like the Virginia Beach oceanfront strip (the high-rise hotels and wide sandy beach are a dead ringer). A good approximate coordinate would be:  
36.8508° N, 75.9780° W (around the 18th–20th Street area on the Virginia Beach boardwalk).
This photo was taken in the live “Pirate Show” arena at LEGOLAND Windsor Resort, Berkshire, England.

This is on the Tongariro Alpine Crossing in Tongariro National Park on New Zealand’s North Island (you’re looking back from near the Red Crater toward the summit of Ngauruhoe and the Emerald‐Lake area).

This looks very much like one of the small squares on the island of Burano in the Venetian lagoon, famous for its brightly painted fishermen’s cottages. I would place it at or very near Piazza Galuppi on Burano, which is at approximately  
Latitude: 45.5043° N  
Longitude: 12.4300° E

Based on the pine‐dominated tree line, the late-morning sun angle and the style of parked SUVs (common in the rural South), my best guess is that this snapshot was taken somewhere in the Piedmont region of Georgia. A plausible coordinate would be near Athens, GA at about 33.95° N, 83.38° W.
This photo was taken on a platform at Shinagawa Station in Tokyo, Japan.
This photo was taken outside the Fashion Show Mall on the Las Vegas Strip in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA.

The watermark in the lower‐left (“CIUDAD REAL CARNAVAL 13-3-2011”) makes it clear this parade is taking place in Ciudad Real, Spain. Judging by the wide, pedestrianized avenue with multi‐storey buildings on either side (a common scene on Calle Palma or Calle Corral), a very plausible set of coordinates for this shot would be right around the city’s main carnival route:  

Approximate location:  
Latitude: 38.9867° N  
Longitude: –3.9271° W  

That places you on one of the principal stretches through downtown Ciudad Real during the carnival procession.

A plausible match for this scene is the outdoor amphitheater area on Princeton University’s campus in New Jersey, just off Washington Road. The approximate coordinates are:

Latitude: 40.3467° N  
Longitude: 74.6514° W
This photograph was taken in the Main Quad arcade of Stanford University, in Stanford, California.
This scene is of a group of “square dancers” practicing in the Temple of Heaven Park in Beijing, China.
This picture was taken in the United States – in front of a Texaco gas station in Texas.

A reasonable guess would be that this snapshot was taken in a small town square in the northeastern state of Bahia, Brazil – for example, somewhere around Feira de Santana. An approximate coordinate for that area would be:  
Latitude: 12.2667° S  
Longitude: 38.9667° W
This photo was taken in Japan (a quiet Tokyo side‐street).

This image almost certainly shows a traditional Bavarian Maibaum (Maypole) being erected in front of the red‐louvered façade of the Museum Brandhorst in Munich’s Kunstareal. The museum sits at Amalienstraße 31, 80538 München, and its approximate coordinates are:  

   48.1481° N, 11.5784° E
